awd_titl_txt: RUI: Charge Modified Antibody for Robust and Directional Adsorption onto Gold Nanoparticles
awd_abstract_narration:
The need to protect against biological threats and to develop effective drug therapies requires the development of novel detection strategies.   The unique properties of gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) make them candidates for materials used in detection technologies. Critical for the success of emerging detection technologies is the attachment of proteins, i.e., antibodies, onto the surface of the AuNPs. Despite extensive efforts in the area of antibody-AuNP conjugation chemistry, current attachment chemistries are not universally applicable to all antibodies, often diminish the function of the antibody, and result in compounds with limited stability. In an effort to address these challenges and to realize the full potential of AuNP-enabled assays, Dr. Jeremy Driskell and his research group at Illinois State University are investigating the underlying principles of the antibody-AuNP interaction.  This research is conducted with the support of the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program. These studies will promote the rational design of highly active and stable antibody-AuNP conjugates. The project provides an intense research experience to undergraduate students who learn advanced analytical techniques and gain an appreciation for a multidisciplinary approach to problem solving. Additionally, Dr. Driskell and his undergraduate students participate in the Illinois Summer Research Academy, an educational outreach program that provides high school students from across the nation with an opportunity to work in a research laboratory.  

Despite many successful examples of antibody-AuNP conjugates, immobilization chemistry still presents a challenge. Direct adsorption of the antibody onto AuNPs is often effective; however, adsorption conditions vary among proteins in an unpredictable manner and the activity of the conjugate is variable. Dr. Driskell's research seeks to identify the underlying principles that cause some antibodies to adsorb onto AuNPs to form stable, highly active conjugates, while other antibodies adsorb weakly and/or exhibit poor binding activity. Dr. Driskell's lab investigates the adsorption dynamics of antibodies onto AuNPs by measuring the adsorption affinity, orientation, reversibility, and displacement by other proteins. Antibodies are chemically modified to precisely alter the protein charge. A systematic investigation into adsorption elucidates the foundational principles needed to build a predictive model for effective surface modification. These efforts support Dr. Driskell's long-term goal of developing a strategy to immobilize antibodies onto AuNPs to form highly active, oriented, and stable conjugates for use in AuNP-enabled immunoassays.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Gold nanoparticles are an integral part of many emerging technologies for diagnostic testing, biomedical imaging, and drug delivery. The modification of the nanoparticle surface with an immobilized antibody is critical to enable selective binding to target specific analytes. This project aimed to identify underlying principles responsible for the adsorption dynamics of antibodies onto gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) by measuring adsorption affinity, orientation, reversibility, and displacement by other proteins. The primary hypothesis was that the adsorption behavior correlates with protein charge; thus, a second thrust was to chemically modify the antibodies to precisely modulate protein charge and promote antibody adsorption onto gold nanoparticles with a preferred orientation. Initial studies established that solution pH is an effective means to manipulate protein surface charge. Extensive characterization of the formed conjugate confirmed that the strength of the protein-nanoparticle interaction was independent of protein charge; however, the protein charge substantially impacted the orientation of the adsorbed protein. Subsequently, a facile means of chemically modifying the lysine residue on the protein was developed to systematically control protein charge for manipulating orientation. Resulting from chemical modification studies, a key finding was that thiols can be added to proteins to control the total number of free thiols on each protein molecule, and the chemically modified protein remains stable. This chemical modification protocol allows for controlling adsorption affinity through facile chemical treatment of protein. Additionally, chemical modification to install thiol functional groups on the protein surface minimized protein unfolding upon adsorption to the nanoparticle, which is critical to maintain biological function. The results of this project clearly reveal the combined benefit of a positively charged functional group and adjacent thiol to facilitate oriented and irreversible binding of the protein on the AuNP and will be the foundational evidence in support of improved methods for bioconjugation.

The broader impacts of this work are three-fold. First, the insights gained in this project provide a generalized pathway to immobilize antibody onto gold nanoparticles to form highly active, oriented, and stable conjugates for use in emerging technologies. Second, this project directly supported the training and education of undergraduate and graduate students. Participating students were provided an opportunity to learn current techniques across multiple disciplines, present at national scientific meetings, and publish in high quality journals. High school students participated in this project through the Illinois Summer Research Academy, an intense, supervised one-week research experience that develops scientific inquiry skills not possible through conventional teaching laboratories. Third, this project provided funds to purchase a dynamic light scattering instrument. While the instrument was dedicated to the project, it was made available to the entire department to improve the physical resources that form infrastructure.
